topic_seeds.description: Dealing with family dynamics and expectations
Feeling isolated and disconnected from others
Feeling overwhelmed by work demands and deadlines
Feeling overwhelmed by work demands and deadlines (relatively straightforward)

exchanges.user:
Hey. so been thinking about reaching out for a while now and figured i should just do it lol. work has been pretty brutal lately, like deadlines are just stacking up and im not even sure how im supposed to get through all of it. my manager keeps adding things to the list but somehow the timeline never changes? its wild.

also been kinda weird with my family. my parents called yesterday and they were doing the whole "so whats the plan for your future" thing again. tbh i love them but it gets exhausting when they have this vision of what im supposed to be doing and im just like... idk i'm trying to figure it out? my dad especially gets this tone where he thinks im not being ambitious enough or whatever.

anyway the work stress is the thing thats really getting to me rn. been sleeping worse and just feeling kinda scattered during the day. thought maybe talking to someone might help bc ive never really done this before.
exchanges.assistant:
Thanks for reaching out. Sounds like you've been holding this for a while, and that last bit about work stress really affecting your sleep and focus—that's a lot to carry alone.

**The work situation:** Your manager adding tasks without adjusting timelines isn't you imagining things—that's a real problem. When the goalposts keep moving but the deadline doesn't, it sets you up to feel like you're failing even when you're doing everything you can. What happens when you push back or ask about priorities? Or does that conversation not really feel like an option right now?

**Your parents:** That "what's the plan" conversation with the tone behind it—I can hear how exhausting that is. You love them, and also it sounds like their vision for you doesn't quite match where you actually are. Your dad's "not ambitious enough" vibe—does that land on you like disappointment, or more like pressure to perform a certain way?

**Sleep and feeling scattered:** When stress ramps up at work and you're also navigating family stuff, your body starts running on fumes. The scattered feeling during the day and worse sleep at night—they feed each other. One question: when you say "worse," what does that look like? Trouble falling asleep, waking up in the middle of the night, or just not feeling rested even when you do sleep?

You mentioned you've never done this before—what made now feel like the right time to start?

exchanges.user:
yeah so i actually tried talking to my manager about the timeline thing. didnt go great lol. he basically said "well these are all priorities" which like... ok? doesnt really answer the question. felt like he was saying theyre all equally important which makes no sense. i just kind of shut down after that and said ok whatever.

anyway on the sleep front its more like i fall asleep fine but then im up at like 3am just thinking about work stuff. like my brain wont shut off. and then im exhausted the next day which makes everything feel worse.

the family thing got messier too. my mom texted asking if i wanted to come home for my dads birthday next month. and idk maybe this is dumb but like... i dont really want to go. feels like im gonna walk in there and immediately get asked about work and relationships and all this stuff and i just cant do that rn. but if i dont go my dad will be upset and my mom will be disappointed. so now ive got that sitting in my head too.

feeling kinda trapped tbh. like everything is just piling up and i dont have good options anywhere? work sucks, family stuff feels obligatory, and im just tired all the time.
exchanges.assistant:
**The manager conversation:** "These are all priorities" is a non-answer, and your brain clocked that immediately. It's a way of avoiding the actual problem—which is that he's overloading you without giving you a way to succeed. The "shut down and said ok whatever" response makes total sense—what else are you supposed to do when the person with power won't engage with reality? That said, shutting down in the moment probably left you carrying all the frustration with nowhere for it to go. What would it feel like to name that directly to him: "If they're all equal priorities, I need help understanding which ones can move or what comes off my plate"? Or does that feel too risky right now?

**The 3am brain:** Falling asleep fine but waking up at 3am with work thoughts—that's your nervous system trying to problem-solve when it should be resting. Your brain thinks if it just thinks hard enough, it'll figure out how to do the impossible (meet all those deadlines). But it can't, because the problem isn't solvable by you alone—it's a structural issue with your workload. One thing that might help: when you wake up at 3am, try this—keep a notepad by your bed. Write down whatever your brain is stuck on (even if it's "same work stuff again"), then tell yourself: "I've captured it, I'll deal with it tomorrow." Sometimes externalizing the loop gives your brain permission to let go. Worth trying?

**Your dad's birthday:** This isn't dumb. You're imagining walking into that house and immediately getting interrogated about work (which is a disaster right now) and relationships (which you didn't mention, so I'm guessing that's another sore spot), and your body is saying "I can't handle that right now." That's not avoidance—that's self-preservation. The trapped feeling makes sense: go and get pummeled with questions you don't have answers to, or don't go and deal with guilt and disappointment. 

Here's a question: what if there's a third option? What if you went, but set a boundary ahead of time? Like texting your mom: "I'm coming for Dad's birthday and I'm really looking forward to celebrating him. I'm dealing with some work stress right now, so I'm asking in advance—can we keep the visit focused on the good stuff and save the 'life plans' conversation for another time?" It's not perfect, and they might not honor it perfectly, but at least you've named it. Does that feel possible, or does even saying that feel too hard right now?

**The "trapped" feeling:** Everything piling up, no good options, exhausted all the time—that's not just stress, that's overwhelm. Your system is maxed out. Work won't let up, family feels like an obligation you can't win at, and sleep isn't recharging you. When you say "trapped," what's the thing that feels most stuck? The work situation, the family dynamics, or something else?

exchanges.user:
ugh ok so i actually tried the notepad thing and like... it kinda worked? woke up at 3am last night and wrote down "deadline for client project is impossible" and then i could actually fall back asleep. felt weird but also kinda nice to not just be spinning in my head for two hours. so thats something i guess.

but then today at work it got worse. my manager pulled me into a meeting and basically said they're bringing on another contractor to "help with the load" which sounds good except like... that means im gonna have to onboard them and explain everything ive been doing and thats just MORE work on top of everything else. i didnt say anything in the meeting bc i was just too tired to deal with it. felt like if i opened my mouth id either cry or yell so i just sat there.

also havent decided about my dads birthday yet. mom sent another text today asking for a headcount for catering lol. like shes already planning assuming im coming. idk maybe i should just go and deal with it. or maybe im being selfish for even considering not going. tbh im kinda spiraling about it which is dumb bc its a month away still.
exchanges.assistant:
**The 3am notepad:** That's great that you tried it and it actually worked. "Deadline for client project is impossible" on paper at 3am, then back to sleep—your brain got to hand the problem off instead of chewing on it for two hours. That's exactly what the technique is supposed to do. The fact that it felt weird makes sense; you're interrupting a pattern your brain has been running for a while. Keep using it when you wake up—it might not work every time, but you've got evidence now that it can help.

**The contractor situation:** They're "helping" by adding onboarding work to your already impossible load. That's not help—that's making your short-term situation worse to maybe improve things later. And you sitting there too exhausted to speak because opening your mouth felt like it would either be crying or yelling—that's your system telling you it's completely maxed out. You didn't say anything because you didn't have anything left to give.

Here's the thing: you shutting down in that meeting is a data point. You're not able to advocate for yourself right now because you're running on empty. That's not a character flaw—that's what happens when someone is overloaded for too long. But it also means the situation isn't going to change unless something shifts. What would it look like to send your manager an email after the fact? Something like: "I want to make the contractor onboarding work, but I need to be realistic—adding onboarding to my current workload means something else has to move. Can we talk about what gets deprioritized while I'm getting them up to speed?" Does that feel doable, or is even writing that email too much right now?

**Your dad's birthday:** Your mom's already planning catering and assuming you're coming, which puts pressure on you to just say yes and deal with it. And now you're spiraling about whether you're being selfish for even considering not going—but here's what I'm hearing: you're not avoiding the birthday because you don't care. You're trying to protect yourself from walking into a situation that feels overwhelming when you're already barely holding it together. That's not selfish. That's survival.

The "maybe I should just go and deal with it" option—what does "deal with it" actually mean? Grit your teeth through the weekend, absorb whatever questions come your way, then come home even more depleted? Or is there a version where you go and actually set a boundary (like the text I suggested last time)? Because if "deal with it" means suffer through it silently, that's not a real option—that's just more of what's already not working.

One other thing: you said "it's a month away still" like that means you shouldn't be stressed about it yet. But your brain doesn't work that way. If it's unresolved and sitting there, it's going to keep pulling at you. What if you made a decision this week—either "I'm going and I'm setting this boundary with Mom ahead of time" or "I'm not going and I'm going to tell them now"—just to get it off the list of things your brain is trying to solve at 3am? Would that help, or does the decision itself feel impossible right now?

exchanges.user:
so i actually sent that email to my manager. took me like an hour to write it bc i kept deleting and rewriting but i got something out there. he hasnt responded yet which is its own kind of anxiety lol. but at least i said something instead of just sitting there spiraling.

the notepad thing has been helping most nights. still waking up sometimes but like... its better? im actually getting maybe 5-6 hours instead of the broken 3-4 i was getting before.

on the family thing... i texted my mom. told her i needed to talk about boundaries for the visit and that i wasnt ready to discuss work or relationship stuff while im there. she said "ok we can talk about that when you come" which is NOT what i asked for lol but whatever. at least i tried. decided im going bc im tired of feeling guilty about it. figure i'll go for the weekend, smile through it, and then leave. not ideal but better than the guilt spiral.

been thinking about what you said about my manager situation though. like... maybe the problem isnt just the workload? idk this might sound crazy but what if he genuinely doesnt realize hes overloading me? like maybe he thinks im fine with it or something. anyway whatever. work is work.
exchanges.assistant:
**The email to your manager:** An hour of deleting and rewriting, then hitting send anyway—that took real effort when you're already exhausted. The fact that he hasn't responded yet is creating its own loop of "what does the silence mean," but you did the hard part: you named the problem instead of absorbing it silently. That's movement. If he doesn't respond in a few days, it might be worth a gentle follow-up ("Just wanted to make sure this didn't get buried—would love to talk through priorities when you have a chance"), but for now, you've done what you could.

**Sleep progress:** 5-6 hours instead of 3-4 broken hours is real improvement. Your brain is learning that the notepad is a safe place to offload, so it's letting go faster. Still waking up sometimes makes sense—your system is still running hot from everything else—but "better" is better. Keep using it.

**Your mom's response:** "Ok we can talk about that when you come" completely sidesteps what you asked for, which was to set the boundary *now*, not negotiate it in person when you're already there. She might not be dodging intentionally—she might just not understand why it matters to do it ahead of time—but the effect is the same: you don't have the reassurance you were asking for. You decided to go anyway and "smile through it, and then leave"—I hear the resignation in that. You're choosing the guilt-avoidance option over the boundary-setting option, which makes sense when you're already so depleted. Just know: if you go and it's as hard as you're expecting, that's not you failing. That's you walking into a situation you knew would be difficult and getting through it. You can reassess after—whether future visits need stricter boundaries or different terms.

**"Maybe he doesn't realize he's overloading me":** This isn't crazy, but let me offer another angle. It's possible he doesn't realize the *extent* of it, sure. But when you said "these deadlines are stacking up and the timeline isn't changing," and he said "these are all priorities"—that wasn't ignorance. That was him choosing not to engage with your reality. Maybe he's conflict-avoidant, maybe he's overwhelmed himself and can't admit the plan is broken, maybe he genuinely thinks if he just says "it's all important" that solves it. But the effect on you is the same: you're left holding an impossible situation. 

The question isn't whether he realizes it. The question is: even if he doesn't, what does that mean for you? Because if he's not going to change the workload, and your body is already telling you it can't sustain this (3am wake-ups, shutting down in meetings, too tired to speak)—something has to give. What would it look like to let something drop, even if he hasn't given you permission to? Like: what if you just... didn't do one of the lower-priority things this week, and when he asks, you say "I prioritized X and Y because those were time-sensitive—Z didn't fit"? I know that feels risky. But what's the alternative if nothing changes?

exchanges.user:
quick update on the work thing. so i didnt actually drop anything lol. manager responded to my email yesterday and basically said "lets sync up next week to talk through priorities" which is good i guess? but also like... next week. the contractor starts monday. so that conversation is coming too late to actually change anything happening right now.

did the onboarding yesterday and today. its as bad as i thought. this person needs explanations on everything and i keep having to context-switch between helping them and trying to finish my own stuff. got maybe 3 hours of actual focused work done across two days. feel like im further behind now than i was before they "helped."

anyway the sleep thing has been better still. been using the notepad most nights. last night i woke up thinking about the birthday trip which is in like 2.5 weeks now and i hate that im already anxious about it even though part of me knows its probably not gonna be as bad as i think. weird how my brain does that.

also like... idk. been thinking about what you said about letting something drop. obviously i cant actually do that without getting in trouble but like the thought is stuck in my head now. like what if that IS the solution and im just too scared to try it? but then i think about the consequences and im like nah that doesnt make sense.
exchanges.assistant:
**Manager's "let's sync next week":** That response is a perfect example of what you've been dealing with—acknowledging the problem but timing the solution so it doesn't actually help. The contractor started Monday, you're drowning in onboarding, and the priorities conversation is scheduled for after the damage is done. He's not ignoring you, but he's also not acting with urgency that matches your reality. That gap—between "yes we should talk" and actually changing anything—is part of why you're so exhausted.

**Onboarding chaos:** Three hours of focused work across two days because you're context-switching constantly—that's not you being inefficient, that's the predictable result of adding a training load to an already maxed-out system. You're further behind now than before the "help" arrived, which is exactly what you saw coming. And you're still doing it because no one gave you permission to say "I can't onboard them *and* hit my deadlines—which one matters more?" You absorbed the contradiction instead.

**The birthday trip anxiety:** Your brain waking you up about something 2.5 weeks away, even when part of you knows it's probably not going to be as bad as you think—that's not weird, that's what brains do with unresolved situations. You set a boundary with your mom, she didn't really confirm it, and you decided to go anyway and "smile through it." Your brain doesn't have closure on how that's actually going to go, so it keeps running scenarios at 3am. The notepad might help here too—if you wake up spiraling about the trip, write down what you're worried will happen ("Dad will ask about work and I won't have a good answer") and let it go for the night. You've already made the decision to go; your brain doesn't need to solve it anymore, it just hasn't gotten the memo yet.

**The "letting something drop" idea:** It's stuck in your head because on some level you know it's true—if the workload is impossible and no one's fixing it, the only move left is to stop trying to do the impossible. But then you think about consequences and it feels too risky, so you're frozen between knowing something has to give and being too scared to be the one who makes it give. That makes complete sense. You're imagining your manager's reaction, potential fallout, maybe even job security, and all of that feels bigger than the unsustainable grind you're in right now.

Here's what I want to offer: there's a difference between *letting something drop* (which sounds like failure or sabotage) and *explicitly naming trade-offs* (which is just reality). Right now you're trying to do everything and slowly breaking under the weight. What if, in next week's priorities conversation, you came with a list: "Here's what's on my plate. Here's the contractor onboarding time. Here's how many hours a week that leaves for actual work. If we want X and Y done by their deadlines, Z has to move—what do you want me to do?" You're not dropping something in secret. You're forcing him to make the call, out loud, about what's actually possible. Does that feel different than just letting something fall through the cracks? Or does even that conversation feel too confrontational right now?

exchanges.user:
been a few days since we talked and honestly things have gotten messier. the priorities conversation with my manager happened yesterday and it was... fine? like he listened and we actually did narrow things down. said the contractor onboarding could wrap up by end of week and then i'd have more breathing room. sounds good in theory.

but then today the contractor had questions on stuff i thought we already covered and i had to stop what i was doing again. and my manager didnt push back on the client asking for extra revisions on a project i thought was locked. so like... we have priorities now but nobody's actually enforcing them? feels like the decision we made yesterday is already falling apart.

also my sleep has been weird. was doing good with the notepad thing but last couple nights ive been too anxious to even fall asleep in the first place. its like my brain gets ahead of itself before i can even write anything down. been thinking about the birthday trip a lot too which is weird bc im supposedly fine with going now but im definitely not fine lol. my mom keeps sending these casual texts about what time im arriving and my dad probably expects me to act like everything is normal when like... nothing is normal rn.

idk maybe im just spiraling again. the work thing should be better and it technically is but it doesnt feel better? everything still feels impossible.
exchanges.assistant:
**The priorities conversation fallout:** You had the talk, you narrowed things down, your manager said onboarding wraps end of week—and then today the contractor had more questions and the client got extra revisions added without pushback. So the *conversation* happened, but the *protection* didn't. The priorities exist on paper, but in practice nobody's guarding them, which means you're still the one absorbing every new ask that comes in. That's why it technically got better but doesn't feel better—the structure changed, the reality didn't.

This is the thing about that conversation: naming priorities only helps if the person with power actually enforces them. When your manager lets the client add revisions to a "locked" project, or when the contractor keeps pulling you away after onboarding was supposed to be winding down, he's undoing the plan you both just made. You can't enforce those boundaries yourself—you don't have that authority. He has to do it, and he's not. What would it look like to name that directly? Like: "Hey, I want to flag that the onboarding is still taking significant time, and the client revisions got added without adjusting the timeline. I'm worried the priorities we set are getting overridden in real time. How do we protect them?" Does that feel possible, or does it feel like you'd just be complaining at this point?

**Sleep regressing:** The notepad worked when you were waking up at 3am because your brain could offload mid-spiral. But now you're too anxious to fall asleep in the first place, which means the spiral is starting earlier and your brain doesn't even get to the "hand it off" part. That's a sign your baseline anxiety has ratcheted up—probably because the work situation keeps promising relief and then not delivering, and the birthday trip is getting closer without real resolution on how it's going to go.

One thing to try when anxiety is blocking sleep at the start of the night: before you even get into bed, do a "worry dump" on paper. Set a timer for 5 minutes and write down everything that's buzzing—work stuff, family stuff, all of it. You're not solving anything, just getting it out of your head and onto the page. Then tell yourself: "I've written it down. My job right now is to sleep, not to solve these. I'll deal with them tomorrow." Sometimes externalizing *before* bed gives your brain permission to let go when you lie down. Worth trying tonight?

**The birthday trip anxiety:** Your mom's casual texts about arrival time, your dad expecting everything to be normal, and you knowing nothing is normal right now—that dissonance is sitting in your chest. You said you're "supposedly fine with going now but definitely not fine," and I think what's happening is: you made the *decision* to go (to avoid guilt), but you haven't made peace with what going actually means. You're walking into a situation where you'll have to perform normalcy when you're barely holding it together, and your brain knows that's going to cost you something.

You set a boundary with your mom about not discussing work/relationships, and she said "we can talk about that when you come"—which means you still don't know if that boundary will be honored. What if you tried one more time, but more directly? Something like: "Mom, I'm coming for Dad's birthday and I'm looking forward to it. I also need to be clear: I'm dealing with some heavy work stress right now, and I'm not in a place to talk about career plans or my personal life while I'm there. I'm asking you to help me keep the weekend focused on celebrating Dad and being together. Can you do that?" It's not a negotiation—it's a clear request. If she dodges again or says "we'll see," at least you'll know what you're walking into, and you can decide if you want to go anyway or if you need to protect yourself differently. Does that feel doable, or is sending that text going to create more anxiety than it solves?

**"Everything still feels impossible":** You're not spiraling. You're accurately perceiving that the relief you were promised (priorities conversation, contractor help, onboarding wrapping up) hasn't actually materialized. The work situation is still impossible, the family situation is still unresolved, and your body is responding accordingly—sleep is worse again, anxiety is higher. When you say "everything still feels impossible," what's the part that feels most impossible right now? The work because it won't actually change? The trip because you can't control how your family will show up? Or something else?

exchanges.user:
ok so i did the worry dump thing last night and like... it actually helped? fell asleep way faster than the past few nights. wrote down a bunch of stuff and just left it there. weird how that works but im not complaining lol.

work is still a mess though. the contractor situation got worse bc apparently theyre staying longer than the original "end of week" plan. my manager mentioned it super casually today like "oh btw we extended them through next month" and i just... didnt say anything. felt like if i complained again id just be the person whos always upset about stuff. so i sat there and nodded and then spent like an hour in the bathroom just feeling defeated.

the birthday thing though. i actually did text my mom what you suggested, that more direct version about boundaries and celebrating dad. and she... actually responded better? like she said "you're right, lets keep it light and fun" which caught me off guard. maybe shell actually respect it? idk im cautiously optimistic about that which feels weird to say after all the spiraling.

the sleep thing is definitely better with the worry dump. gonna keep doing that. but the work stuff has me feeling pretty trapped again. like i finally got some sleep relief and then work just got worse which feels unfair lol. whats even the point of trying to manage my stress if nothing actually changes at work?
exchanges.assistant:
**The worry dump working:** That's great that you tried it and it actually helped you fall asleep faster. Writing it all down and leaving it there—your brain got the signal that those problems are captured and don't need to be solved right now. The "weird how that works" reaction makes sense; it feels almost too simple to be effective, but you've got proof now that externalizing before bed gives your system permission to rest. Keep using it, especially on nights when your brain is already revving before you lie down.

**The contractor extension:** Your manager casually mentioned they're staying through next month—after you had a whole priorities conversation where onboarding was supposed to wrap up end of week—and you sat there and nodded because speaking up again felt like you'd just be "the person who's always upset about stuff." That defeated hour in the bathroom afterward—that's what happens when you absorb something you know is wrong but don't feel like you have permission to push back on.

Here's the thing: you're not "always upset about stuff." You've raised this issue twice—once in the email, once in the priorities conversation—and both times your manager acknowledged it but then let the situation get worse anyway. Extending the contractor without warning you or adjusting your workload isn't you being overly sensitive; it's him making a decision that directly affects your capacity and not involving you in it. You're not complaining too much. You're noticing a pattern where your reality keeps getting dismissed.

What would it look like to name this one more time, but framed around the broken pattern instead of this specific instance? Something like: "I want to flag something I'm noticing. We had a priorities conversation where onboarding was supposed to wrap up, and now the contractor's extended through next month. This is the second time the plan has shifted without adjusting my workload, and I'm concerned that even when we align on priorities, they're not holding in practice. I need to know: if I raise capacity issues, will the plan actually change, or am I just supposed to absorb whatever comes next?" 

I know that feels confrontational. But right now you're stuck in a loop where you speak up, nothing changes, and then you stop speaking up because it feels pointless. That hour in the bathroom is your body telling you this isn't sustainable. If he responds defensively or dismisses it again, that's actually useful information—it tells you he's not going to protect your boundaries, which means you have to decide what you're willing to tolerate and for how long. Does sending that feel possible, or does it feel like it would just make things worse?

**Your mom's response:** "You're right, let's keep it light and fun"—she actually acknowledged the boundary and agreed to it. That's not what you were expecting after the last dodge, and cautious optimism makes sense. You don't know yet if she'll honor it when you're actually there (talk is easy, follow-through is harder), but she gave you something to hold onto. If she does respect it, the weekend might actually be manageable. If she doesn't, you'll know pretty quickly, and you can leave early or find other ways to protect yourself. Either way, you set a clear boundary and she responded well—that's something.

**"What's the point of managing stress if nothing changes at work?":** This is the question, isn't it? You found a tool that helps with sleep, and that's real—your body is getting more rest, which matters. But the relief feels hollow because the thing *causing* the stress (work being unsustainable and your manager not protecting you) is still there and getting worse. It's like bailing water out of a boat while someone keeps poking new holes in it. The sleep tool helps you survive the flood, but it doesn't fix the boat.

The point of managing your stress right now isn't to make the work situation okay—it's to keep you functional while you figure out what to do about the work situation. Because here's what I'm hearing across the last few weeks: you've tried naming the problem (email, priorities conversation), and it hasn't changed the reality. Your manager keeps saying the right things and then acting like those conversations didn't happen. You're too depleted to keep advocating for yourself in the moment (shutting down in meetings, nodding when the contractor got extended), and the cost of absorbing all this is showing up in your body (sleep issues, bathroom breakdowns, feeling defeated).

So the question isn't really "what's the point of managing stress"—the question is "how long can I stay in this job if the workload stays impossible?" I'm not saying you need to quit tomorrow. But if your manager won't enforce boundaries and you can't enforce them yourself, and the result is that you're constantly underwater—what does that mean for you six months from now? A year from now? What would it look like to start exploring other options, even quietly, just to know you have them?

exchanges.user:
been a couple days and honestly things feel different. like... not better necessarily but like i actually did something about it. sent that email about the broken pattern thing you suggested. manager responded pretty quickly which was surprising. said he "didnt realize the extensions were adding up like that" and wants to talk about it more thoroughly next week instead of just casual hallway conversations.

idk maybe he actually didnt get it before? or maybe he was avoiding it. either way at least theres gonna be an actual meeting about it now instead of me just absorbing changes.

the worry dump thing is still working. been doing it most nights before bed. sleep has been more consistent which honestly feels like a small win when everything else is so messy.

but also like... i've been thinking about what you said at the end there. about the six months, a year from now thing. and like i hate that its stuck in my head because its making me anxious in a different way? like now im not just stressed about keeping up with the impossible workload, im also thinking about whether i should even be here at all. which is like... a bigger question. havent told anyone im thinking about this. just kinda sitting with it.

also the trip is next weekend and im actually nervous but like... different nervous? less spiraly and more like ok im going and whatever happens happens. my mom sent one more text confirming the boundary thing which helped.
exchanges.assistant:
**The email and your manager's response:** You sent it, and he responded quickly saying he "didn't realize the extensions were adding up like that." Whether he genuinely didn't see it or was avoiding it—hard to say. But what matters is: you named the pattern clearly, and instead of another casual dodge, you're getting an actual meeting. That's different. You forced the conversation out of hallway mentions and into a space where it has to be taken seriously. That took effort when you were already exhausted, and it worked. When that meeting happens, you'll find out if he's willing to actually change things or if this is just another round of acknowledgment without action. But either way, you'll have more information about what's actually possible here.

**Sleep consistency:** The worry dump working most nights and sleep being more consistent—that's not a small win, that's a real one. Your body is getting the rest it needs to function, which means you have slightly more capacity to deal with everything else. It doesn't fix the work situation, but it keeps you from running completely empty while you figure out what to do about it.

**The "should I even be here" question:** It's stuck in your head because it's a real question, and your brain knows it. You've spent weeks trying to make an impossible situation work, and now you're looking up and asking "what if the situation itself is the problem?" That's not spiraling—that's clarity starting to break through. And yeah, it creates a different kind of anxiety, because now you're not just managing the day-to-day grind, you're thinking about whether the grind is worth staying in at all. That's a bigger, scarier question than "how do I get through this week's deadlines."
